The 993 911 was sold for the 1995 to 1998 model years and represented the last – and most powerful – generation of air-cooled 911s. Available as a coupe, cabriolet, and Targa, and with rear- or all-wheel drive, the 993 was an evolution of the 964 it replaced with a more modern look and redesigned rear suspension system.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/rkZZOWN.dougs_take: The Lamborghini Gallardo Spyder is a wonderful exotic car with a glorious naturally-aspirated V10, all-wheel drive, and timeless styling. This particular Gallardo Spyder is especially desirable, as it’s finished in the amazing Rosso Vik – and it touts just 12,600 miles. It’s also equipped with some great factory equipment, including the Interior Leather Package II, power-adjustable heated seats, and those beautiful 19-inch Callisto wheels. This Gallardo is also completely unmodified, and it's offered with a clean, accident-free Carfax report, further adding to the appeal. These baby Lambos represent a phenomenal value, and I’m certain the next owner will love all of the driving thrills this Gallardo has to offer.

Launched for 2004, the Gallardo filled a gap in the Lamborghini range that had remained empty for over a decade. It was smaller and more affordable than the V12-powered Murciélago, so it made the brand accessible to a wider target audience and landed in a segment dominated by arch-nemesis Ferrari. With sharp lines and a sonorous V10 engine, the Gallardo remained in production until 2014, when it was replaced by the Huracán. It retired as the best-selling member of the Lamborghini range to date.

https://carsandbids.com/auctions/3Bw508A.dougs_take: BMW wagons are excellent cars, and they've been a huge success on Cars & Bids – no surprise, as they combine excellent driving performance with good practicality. The E61 5 Series was the final 5 Series wagon BMW offered in the U.S. – and this particular example has a LOT going for it. It's a 535i model that touts all-wheel drive and a potent turbocharged 6-cylinder engine, and it's finished in a gorgeous Deep Green Metallic over black color combination. It also features some nice equipment like the Premium and Cold Weather packages, 17-inch Style 277 wheels, a panoramic sunroof, and a Logic7 surround sound system – plus, it's unmodified, which is a great benefit. On top of all that, this 535i wagon comes with a clean, accident-free Carfax report – AND it's offered with the thrill of no reserve.

Called E60 internally, the fifth-generation 5 Series made its American debut for 2004 and the E61 wagon arrived in 2006. Both were styled under the guidance of Chris Bangle and their design left no one indifferent. Inside, the E61 was more luxurious than its predecessor, and it offered drivers a longer list of technology features, but it continued to stand out with engaging handling and a cavernous trunk.
BMW sold 9,885 units of the E61 in America. It was the final 5 Series wagon available here.
